If money talks, the latest dispute to impinge on the Heineken Cup will be settled quickly. When the stakeholders of the tournament's organisers, European Rugby Cup Ltd, gather in Dublin on Tuesday they will be given a choice by Premiership Rugby. Do they want a new television deal with Sky worth £70m over four years from the 2014-15 season, or would they be prepared to give the rights for the Heineken Cup and the Amlin Challenge Cup to BT Vision and earn 50% more?

There would be conditions, with changes to the number of teams taking part in the Heineken Cup and adjustments to the qualification process, making it more merit based than at present, and the four RaboDirect Pro12 countries will be asked to agree to the English and French clubs receiving a greater share of the money generated by sponsorship and television deals.

"That is only fair given that we are the two countries with by far the greatest number of chimney pots and therefore the draw cards for television," said the Saracens' chairman, Nigel Wray. "But because the BT deal involves such a large injection of money, everyone will receive more and what is already a good competition will become even bigger, better and stronger."

Premiership Rugby last week agreed a television deal with BT Vision worth £152m over four years. The biggest part of it, more than £100m, was for the right to televise English clubs in cross-border competition, but the ERC stakeholders will be told that BT are prepared to replace Sky as the principal broadcasters of the whole tournament.

"Everybody wins," said Wray. "There would be so much extra money coming into the European game that we would be able to afford a third tier competition involving teams from the smaller unions. This is not a selfish bid by English and French clubs to grab everything for ourselves: all six competing nations will be better off.

"All we are asking for in return is fairness. Why should the team that finishes bottom of the Pro 12 automatically qualify for the Heineken Cup but clubs in England and France have to give blood to get there? Why should the Amlin Challenge Cup effectively be an Anglo-French tournament? RaboDirect teams should earn the right to be in the Heineken Cup."

There is an acceptance among RaboDirect sides that qualification should be looked at. Edinburgh, Glasgow, Treviso and Zebre know they will be in the Heineken Cup even if they finish at the bottom of the league, but a Welsh region or Irish province could finish fourth and miss out.

The Welsh regions would welcome the extra money, but their union, together with Ireland's, is happy with the qualification process because it allows international players to be regularly rested. The bulk of ERC's board is made up of representatives from unions, with only England, France and Wales having directors from participating teams.

Premiership Rugby is going mob-handed to Dublin. In addition to its ERC director, the chief executive Mark McCafferty and the deputy chairman, Bruce Craig, Bath's owner, will be at the meeting, along with the RFU's representative, Rob Andrew. ERC itself says there can be no deal with BT because of the contract extension it has agreed with Sky, an agreement that the English and French clubs maintain is void because they had already served their notice to pull out of Europe at the end of next season.

If one part of the battle is between the English and French clubs and the Pro12 unions, the other is between Sky, the dominant player in club rugby television in the professional era, and BT, a company with capitalisation 10 times greater than Sky's that sees sports rights as an opportunity to reclaim some of its telephone and broadband business lost to Sky and Virgin Media.

"Sky have been superb for sport, not just rugby," said Wray. "There is now a new and very big player in the market, and competition can only be good. Television income is the lifeblood of our game and the BT deal will help all the Premiership clubs start to balance books, rather than rely on investors like me."

Wray, the longest serving chairman in the Premiership, has been here before: in 1998, when the English clubs pulled out of Europe in protest at power being vested in unions, and in 2006-07 when they, along with France, served notice to withdraw unless they were given a shareholding and a measure of control in commercial matters.

"This is different," he said, "not least because there is a huge television deal on the table. We do not want to pull out of Europe or go to court to challenge the anti-competitive IRB regulation that says clubs, which are small businesses, cannot negotiate their own television deals and there should be no need to because of what is there for everyone. Contrary to some reports, we are united and back Mark McCafferty 100 per cent. There is no reason why this should drag on and on because rugby will be the winner."

Born with a rare neurological condition, 19-year-old Joe Rae has learning difficulties and problems with speech and motility. He is a student at National Star College in Cheltenham, a specialist residential college for young people with complex physical disabilities, where he has hydrotherapy, physiotherapy, lessons in music, dance and life skills and, in his mother's words, has made "extraordinary" progress.

"I got a phone call [from college staff] one night to say that he had been watching television and suddenly wasn't there," says his mother, Edel Rae. "He had pulled himself up on his walking frame – which, in itself, took great physical strength and determination – and taken himself off to his bedroom. It may sound like a small thing, but making a decision to remove himself from a room – something he had never done before – was a huge step forward for Joe."

Education like this doesn't come cheap. There are 61 specialist further education colleges in the UK – most offering residential care – and a place at a college like National Star can cost more than £60,000 a year, and up to £120,000 for students with very complex needs.

As a result, many parents already face a long, hard battle to secure financial support for their child to attend a specialist college, particularly as many are asking for funding for their child to study in a different local authority. But changes to funding for the education of young people with special needs, due to come into force next year, mean things could soon get worse.

Under the new funding arrangements, local authorities will no longer have to "ringfence" funding for school leavers with high levels of need – those identified as needing financial support for their education that is likely to exceed about £10,000 a year. Instead, they will have a budget for all children and young people with high levels of need up to the age of 25. There are fears in the sector that resources will not be directed where they are needed most.

One concern is that with the compulsory participation age due to rise to 17 from next year (and 18, from 2015), giving local authorities a statutory duty to provide education for that age group means there will be "less in the pot" for older learners, as Alison Boulton, chief executive of the Association of National Specialist Colleges (Natspec), puts it. She is also worried that some local authorities, which, like most public sector organisations are facing considerable budget cuts, will prioritise saving money over meeting the needs of young people. She says: "Some local authorities' attitude is 'we're not interested in the Rolls-Royce, we just want something that goes'."

Typically, local authorities will offer young people like Joe three or four days of education at a local provider, often travelling by taxi or specially arranged transport.

And as Rae found out, there can be a big difference between what parents and local authorities deem suitable education for a young person with disabilities. She recalls a "heartbreaking" visit to a local day centre, which catered for an age range of 18 to 80, that her local authority argued could provide for Joe's needs. "I said: 'I don't think it's appropriate for 18-year-olds to be with 80-year-olds – people with Alzheimer's – or vice versa.' When my other son left school, nobody suggested it would be OK to mix with 80-year-olds so why is that OK for Joe? While the staff were doing their best, there was nothing in the way of learning or age-appropriate activities."

A residential college placement gives students the opportunity to develop social skills and independence and, crucially, to mix with others like themselves. Kathryn Rudd, principal of National Star College, recalls one student saying: "Coming here, for the first time, I haven't felt 'special'. I didn't have to get on a special bus to get here, I don't have to do 'special' things … I'm just 'normal' here."

For some young people, this can make a huge difference – helping them to develop the skills to volunteer, work or live semi-independently, something they are far less likely to do if they are "coming home from college in a taxi and sitting at home on their own all evening," says Rudd.

While some local authorities are clued up about the benefits of specialist colleges, others lack understanding and expertise. One parent – who did not wish to be named for fear it would jeopardise the funding bid for her son – told the Guardian: "My local authority told me I only wanted my son to go to a specialist college because I couldn't handle having him at home … that really hurt. Like any parent, I just want the best possible education for my son."

According to Anne Price, director of education and life skills at David Lewis College in Cheshire, and Natspec chair, the experience is typical of the "postcode lottery" faced by parents. "If you're in a good local authority, with good staff, you'll get a good deal, and if you aren't, you'll get nothing. I have never known it as bad as this, ever."

Placing young people who would benefit from specialist further education in local colleges or training providers may help local authorities make short-term savings, but, in the long term, it can prove more costly. A report published by the National Audit Office last year showed that equipping a young person with moderate learning disabilities with the skills to live semi-independently – rather than in fully supported housing – could reduce their lifetime support costs by around £1m.

And as Jane Stone, whose daughter Kate has Down's syndrome, found out, even the short-term savings can be negligible. After being turned down for funding for a specialist college, on the grounds that it was too expensive, Kate was offered a few hours at a college more than 10 miles away. Stone and her husband – both accountants – carried out a financial comparison of the costs of educating their daughter at a specialist college compared to a more local provider. "We did a spreadsheet that showed if she stayed at home, social services would have to look after her from 10am-7pm, because we are out at work. So when you start adding up the cost of social care support at £20 an hour, taxi fares to the college, respite care … it doesn't take long to stack up. That was basically how we won [their case for her to go to a specialist college] because we were able to show that [the alternative] wasn't cheaper."

Stone readily admits that persistent parents who make a fuss can be successful in overturning local authorities' decisions. Time and money help too. As well as countless hours spent reading reports, writing letters and meeting with council officials, Stone spent "two or three grand on a lawyer, just to write some sniffy letters". Rae started a fundraising organisation – the Joe Rae Trust – and organised coffee mornings, talent shows and sponsored walks to raise funds to help fight Joe's case (and to put towards his college fees if the local authority refused funding).

But under the new, even more complicated funding arrangements, there is a concern that only the most sharp-elbowed parents will be able to find their way around the system. "What happens to those young people who haven't got someone behind them fighting every step of the way and threatening to take everyone on the planet to court?" asks Rudd.

And, if local authorities are increasingly reluctant to hand over the cash to fund young people to study at specialist FE colleges, it could threaten the colleges' very existence. "We just don't know what this new system will be like … but it has the potential to destabilise the future of specialist provision," she says.

A DfE spokesperson said the idea of the new policy was to make sure councils worked with health services. "We will also be offering young people and parents the option of a personal budget so that they can have more control over how their support is delivered."

Profit and loss

A further education college that seemed poised this year to become the first state-funded institution in England to be run for profit has been forced to reconsider a planning application to build on its sports fields after a major protest by residents.

Barnfield College in Luton had hoped to develop its 14.3-hectare (35-acre) site with a new college building, an 88-bed care home, up to 39 houses and a "free school", while also redeveloping its sports pitches. But campaigners who oppose the £25m plans say 382 people had complained as of last week, while Luton borough council's planning application website has 27 pages of letters of complaint.

Residents seem most unhappy that a substantial part of the area, which, they say, was passed by the local authority to the college free of charge in the 1990s and is used extensively as open green space by the community, would be lost, and that traffic would grow significantly.

In March, the Guardian revealed how Barnfield, which is part of a chain of academies and free schools, would become a profit-making body if plans to allow a proportion of its financial surplus to be paid to shareholders won the approval of its board. The notion of a profit-making institution gaining from what had been publicly maintained land had added to campaigners' ire, said Rubina Zaidi of the Barnfield Development Action Group.

However, Barnfield says its original planning application had been "completely withdrawn" and also that the profit-making proposal had not yet gone ahead. The college is now looking at "new ways to enhance and develop the site that will entirely remove the various concerns raised by local people", says Alan Euinton, its principal.

Luton borough council says it has yet to receive notification that the application was being withdrawn.

Legal wrangle for teachers

Staff who were left without redundancy payments or a job this month after two comprehensives closed and a free school opened on the site of one of them, could face a wait until the new year until their situation is resolved.

Former teachers and support staff at St Wilfrid's high and St George of England high, both in Sefton, Merseyside, have been caught in the middle of a legal dispute between the local authority, the free school's trustees and the Department for Education.

The local authority argues that under employment law, staff jobs at the two schools must transfer to the Hawthorne's free school, meaning no redundancy payments apply. But the Hawthorne's, backed by the DfE, says it is under no obligation to take on workers from the two closing schools.

Sefton council is now seeking to challenge the DfE and free school's position in the high court, with an application expected to be submitted this week. Some staff are pursuing the matter through employment tribunals, but a former St George teacher says hearings are unlikely to start until December or January. "We have been left in limbo, and people are getting increasingly outraged."

Minister's useful A-level

And finally … does Matthew Hancock, the new further education minister, have an FE past? Not, it would seem, if you looked on his personal Conservative party website before his appointment two weeks ago. It simply listed his education as primary school followed by King's school, Chester, then Oxford and Cambridge. But hours after his appointment, West Cheshire College – where he is said to have gained an A-level in computing – was added, though initially in a different font from the rest of the entry.

The apparently frantic rejigging was revealed by the trade title FE Week. Nick Linford, its managing editor, says: "Cynics might suggest the new minister was not bothered about his FE past until it became politically useful. Personally, I think it is good to see it there, in pride of place no doubt."

Anti-abortion protesters who displayed pictures of aborted foetuses outside a clinic offering pregnancy terminations have been cleared of public order offences.

Andrew Stephenson and Kathryn Sloane, members of Abort67, were accused of intimidating women who went for abortion services at a clinic run by Bpas in Brighton.

A district judge sitting at Brighton magistrates court found them not guilty of displaying material that is threatening, abusive or insulting, under public order legislation.

Abort67 has been demonstrating outside the clinic for five years.

The pressure group Abortion Rights said the verdict "demonstrates that the current law is inadequate to protect women from intimidation by hardline anti-abortion activists. It will be viewed as a green light for them to continue their aggressive campaign tactics. As a society we should be able to guarantee the privacy and safety of those seeking to access a legal medical treatment."

Andrea Minichiello Williams, chief executive of the Christian Legal Centre, which represented the accused pair, said: "The dismissal of these charges will be welcomed by all who value freedom of speech and expression."

She said they were seeking an urgent meeting with leaders of the Association of Chief Police Officers about the interpretation of the Public Order Act, "to explore whether better guidance can be drawn up over the policing of such activities, especially those motivated by religious convictions".

Bpas said it did not take a position on the legality of the protest but questioned its morality. "What takes place on a regular basis outside our clinic is not about debate or changing public opinion – it is simply about causing distress to individual women on what may already be a difficult day," it said.

It's all go in Sharman Macdonald's She Town. The Dundee mill-workers are angry because their wages are being cut; the choir is auditioning to accompany Paul Robeson, the singer and civil rights activist, at his concert in the city's Caird Hall; and the politically committed are preparing to go and fight the fascists in the Spanish civil war.

With a background of child mortality, teenage pregnancy and squalid living conditions, the play identifies a potentially revolutionary period in Dundee's history, not least since a major part of the workforce was female. Appropriately, director Jemima Levick has brought together 44 women in this professional/community collaboration and with striking results: they move about the stage in the shadow of Alex Lowde's towering tenement set, creating the impression of a city teeming with life.

A shame, then, that it comes across as so joyless a play. The women are always bickering (about what, it's often hard to say); but worse, they are downtrodden rather than fervent, their anger too easily cowed by reactionary ideology. When the mill-owner's wife accuses them of "politics borne of envy", adding, "that's no politics at all", they are oddly quick to agree. With so many people on stage and with such polemical material, you would expect something celebratory and defiant. This seems muted and humourless.

That's not a charge you could level at Chris Rattray's The Mill Lavvies, which has no political ambitions but offers much jolly banter as it follows the working day in a cloth factory from the perspective of the gents' loos. Set 30 years after She Town, when it's the Beatles who'll be playing the Caird Hall, it's a minor comedy made special by the songs of Michael Marra, given spirited performances by the six actors in Andrew Panton's good-hearted production.

James Antle: 'Problems with the conservative base limit his freedom'

In a conference call with reporters Monday morning, the Romney campaign said their candidate was getting ready to release more detailed information about his plans to reduce the deficit and strengthen the middle class. As important as the plans themselves was the thinking behind this move.

According to Romney strategist Ed Gillespie, the idea was to introduce the voters to Mitt Romney the man at the Republican National Convention. Now, as we are heading into the homestretch, Americans want to hear policy specifics from the candidates.

This is interesting because Romney has built his campaign on several assumptions. The first is that voters wouldn't really be paying attention during the summer and would start to really focus on the race during the fall. Therefore, it was safe to allow the Obama campaign to outspend Romney 2-1 in several swing states – not counting assists from Super Pacs on both sides – and saturate the airwaves with ads, because nobody would watching. Romney would wait to open his wallet and launch his air attack when the voters were engaged.

There's political science data that contradicts this theory, as does the recent example of John Kerry's 2004 presidential campaign. Eight years ago, a shaky incumbent took to the airwaves early to define his little known and less liked challenger. Kerry never recovered. Romney is betting he'll be different.

The second assumption is that the election will be almost entirely a referendum on Barack Obama's performance in office, and that the economy makes it very unlikely the president can be re-elected. This, too, carries risk. Romney has done relatively little to define himself or his campaign. Weak economic growth has occasionally been compatible with presidential reelection. And a large percentage of the American people still blame George W Bush for the economy. The recession didn't begin under Obama's watch, even if his policies haven't stimulated much of a recovery.

Now Romney seems to be assuming that the remaining swing voters can be reached by filling them in on the policy details he has left fuzzy throughout the campaign. This may be due to a dent in Romney's tax advantage caused by the Obama campaign's assertions that the Republican's tax plan would raise the burden on the middle class. But there's little evidence "low-information undecideds" will suddenly be turned by learning how Romney would regulate energy or tweak marginal tax rates.

The most valid of Romney's assumptions is that his problems with the conservative base limit his freedom of movement. He can't pivot – as he clearly would like to – on healthcare and immigration, and might also want to on abortion. By itself, this isn't a problem, since this is shaping up to be a base election. But it has limited Romney's ability to develop a critique of Obama that goes beyond the committed Republican voter, as evidenced even by his Cairo embassy statement.

Internal campaign sniping aside, what Romney is left with is essentially hoping that anti-Obama sentiment is large enough to keep him within the margin of error. Then, on election day, undecided voters could break heavily enough to put him over the top. It could work; it could be a strategy for topping out at around 48% of the vote.

But it doesn't seem like the ambitious pursuit of a mandate some conservatives expected when Romney tapped Paul Ryan as his running-mate.

James Antle is editor of the Daily Caller News Foundation and a senior editor at the American Spectator

Cheri Jacobus: 'Romney's Libya criticism could have been stronger'

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney's reaction to the attacks and murders of American Consul to Libya Chris Stevens and several of his colleagues was not a faux pas, as Democrats and their cheerleaders in the media claim. In fact, his criticism could have been stronger for maximum impact.

In 1980, when Iran held 52 Americans hostage, thumbing their nose at "threats" by President Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan sent a strong message that was unmistakable in its resolve: when Reagan became president of the United States, Iran's Ayatollah Khomeni would face the harsh reality of what a strong American president would do in the face of a hostage situation. Reagan was Carter's opponent in the election, and the incumbent president's weakness and impotence, and their danger to America, had developed into a key issue in the final weeks of the campaign. Carter, like Obama, also had failed domestically – on the economy, gas prices, and joblessness – and looked for others to blame.

In September 1980, Carter was leading Reagan in the polls by 8 points. But in the face of domestic and foreign policy failures mirroring those of President Barack Obama today, the incumbent lost to Reagan on election day. America's choice for leadership was confirmed as the correct decision when Iran released the American hostages, just as Ronald Reagan was placing his hand on the Bible and being sworn in as president. While pro-Carter historians have twisted themselves into pretzels trying to implicate Carter as the man behind ending the hostage crisis, the facts speak otherwise.

President Obama has proven to be weak-kneed, caving to Islamic extremists, including al-Qaida, by perp-walking an American film-maker out of his home for producing a film on Islam our enemies in the Middle East are falsely claiming as the reason for the anti-American riots and murders across the region. But the truth is beginning to haunt Obama, as we now know the attacks were planned, and the Obama administration was made aware of the impending doom, but ignored the information and declined to share it with Ambassador Stevens and others.

That President Obama chose to skip six days of security briefings during that period, and more than half in his presidency, sets him up for comparisons to failed President Carter – and for being held accountable for placing Americans overseas at risk. As it becomes apparent that President Obama misled the American public, and that Americans died as a consequence of his inaction, his presidency should be over.

Yet the media seem to remain intent on protecting Obama, even in light of the danger his incompetence has proven to present.

While most polls show Romney trailing Obama nationally, the most accurate from 2008, Rasmussen, shows Romney leading. However, Obama appears to have the edge in more of the key battleground states Romney needs in order to win. Despite overblown reports of the Romney campaign infighting, which nearly match recent stories about conflict among top Obama aides, the Republican nominee needs to be able to turn on a dime and fully address Obama's dangerous foreign policy – or rather lack thereof – while hitting Obama on the tanked economy, $16tn national debt, 23 milllion jobless, and Obamacare.

In short, Mitt Romney needs to understand that the media is against him. He must not utter anything superfluous to his core message – eliminating the media's scope to focus on anything other than substance: they can't quote him on what he doesn't say. Romney's argument on substance versus Obama's lies and obfuscation will win the day.

Cheri Jacobus is a Republican political strategist, pundit and writer

Matt Lewis: 'Romney now needs strong debate performances'

If someone isn't comfortable in his own skin – if he doesn't really know who he is – everyone can tell. Campaigns are similar, and Mitt Romney's campaign has been looking self-divided lately.

Despite a few flirtations with boldness (including the selection of Representative Paul Ryan as his running-mate), the Romney campaign always reverts to passivity. This is surprising and unfortunate, inasmuch as the boldness has usually worked.

The strategy also seems to imply a belief in the (probably) false premise that a bad economy would automatically doom Obama – and that Romney could win by simply raising campaign cash, running perfunctory TV ads, and staying above the fray and under the radar. (Today, the theory that the 2012 election is solely a referendum on Obama seems quaint. But the Romney campaign might have been the last to notice.)

This premise has manifested itself in various ways, including Romney's single-minded focus on the economy. Supporters call this "message discipline", but being elected president is about more than any one facet of political life – no matter how important that facet might be. Romney's Middle East comments last week were ill-timed, to be sure, but they were at least a recognition that the 2012 campaign is also about foreign policy, national security, and yes, even social issues.

Interestingly, the notion that a Republican could win on the economy alone doesn't seem to jibe with history. Liberals can always promise more giveaways – a fact that can make them seem more appealing during tough economic times. Sure, Ronald Reagan defeated Jimmy Carter in 1980 because of malaise – but there was also the Iranian hostage crisis.

To win, Romney must give voters a reason to vote for him – not just a reason to oppose Obama. He must present a coherent worldview that contrasts him with Obama's interrelated policies. It is important that we see his vision. And yes, there should be some specifics. The notion that he can skate by without providing details – that he can run out the clock and hope we don't check his homework – won't fly.

There are three big moments in general election campaigns: The selection of a running mate, the convention, and the debates. In the next 50 or so days, Mitt Romney has to find a way to get his groove back – and this will clearly require strong debate performances.

Despite the campaign infighting and ill-advised press conference during last week's Middle East turmoil, Mitt Romney can still win this election. Like a sports team on a losing streak things look bleak. But wining covers a multitude of sins.

If Romney catches fire – which is still possible – his campaign problems suddenly look trivial. As they say, nothing succeeds like success.

Matt Lewis is a senior contributor on politics to the Daily Caller

Jim Geraghty: 'Just being "Not Obama" isn't going to be enough'

There are three changes the Romney campaign ought to make immediately.

1) Enough with "Obama isn't working." Yes, we know. It's obvious. No one needs to be reminded that unemployment is high. When you spend so much time repeating what everyone already knows, people begin to wonder if you really have that much else to say.

2) The Romney campaign – Romney, most of his surrogates, and its ads and web videos – needs to connect the dots a lot more. If you watch Bill Clinton talk about a policy, there's a particular rhythm: first, here's the problem; second, here's what's causing the problem; third, here's what we're going to do; fourth, here's how it will work; and fifth, here's the result you'll see when it works.

3) The campaign just needs to move faster: news cycles come and go without Romney managing to staple his agenda and ideas to the passing events. Last week would have been a golden opportunity to discuss what Romney really thinks of the Arab Spring: did America look at the uprisings in the region too optimistically? Is the Arab world ready for democracy, or is that just setting the stage for demagogues and/or Islamists? Have any of our public diplomacy efforts in recent years really paid off, or have they amounted to feelgood talk?

And when Ben Bernanke and the Fed enacted QE3 last week, didn't that seem like a golden opportunity to showcase the Romney campaign argument about how the US economy is in a rut where all traditional methods of "stimulus" have proven disappointing? And how about the expected upcoming release of the Department of Justice inspector general's report on the "Fast and Furious" scandal? That's a perfect opportunity to make an address on the "culture of unaccountability" in Washington – found in the GSA (general services administration), as well as the DOJ – and how a Romney administration would fix that.

Opportunities come and go. But the recent polling suggests that just being "Not Obama" isn't going to be enough this cycle.

Jim Geraghty writes the Campaign Spot blog for National Review Online

The emergence of Norwegian saxophonist Marius Neset last year confirmed that this charismatic newcomer – who looks like the young Leonardo DiCaprio and can sound like a fusion of Jan Garbarek and the late Michael Brecker – had the energy, technique, and idiomatic range for a run of albums that could all sound completely different. This year's contrasting successor to his Golden XPlosion debut with British mentor Django Bates features Neset's sax in conversation with the young Norwegian tuba maestro Daniel Herskedal. Neset and Herskedal played music from their new Neck of the Woods session as part of Edition Records' mini-festival at Kings Place.

The pair opened with Abdullah Ibrahim's poignant theme The Wedding, explored in pure-toned sax falsettos over didgeridoo-like growls, and stately, slow-moving counterpoint. Then they whisked through the prancing, folksy, Garbarek-like Ara's Dance, a solo exposition of slurred low sounds and layers of high, guitar-toned pedal-effects from Herskedal (who uses electronics imaginatively), and played a graceful soprano sax ballad, The Christmas Song. Neset returned to the tenor sax for an unaccompanied improvisation, turning his imaginative virtuosity up to full power: circuitous runs resolved in quietly inquisitive gestures and he showed secure control of delicate high sounds way above the instrument's register. The pair wound up with another sprightly folk-dance, which sounded both Scandinavian and Anatolian. Neset and Herskedal's music typified the accessible adventurousness that marks out Edition Records – as did the playing of the young British saxophonist Josh Arcoleo, whose forceful band featuring brilliant pianist Ivo Neame performed after the Norwegians on stage. Arcoleo is not only a sax improviser of patience and poise, he's a composer of post-bop tunes that leap out of the generic crowd.

Arctic sea ice cover reached a record low this summer. The latest rate loss is 50% higher than experts predicted. And now there are alarming reports of a reservoir of the potent greenhouse gas methane, which could be released in Antarctica if the ice continues to melt so quickly there.

The Guardian Teacher Network has some useful resources to explore climate change and the particular issues in the Arctic and Antarctic.

A great introduction to the subject is to watch this time-lapse video of sea ice melting in the Arctic this summer from April to September. This news story explains what has happened this year and how scientists believe this could be a sign of long-term climate change.

This resource Ice melt in Greenland from The Day on the sudden and dramatic melt over the summer asks: explains the news story and the issues simply and asks, is the melt to do with global warming?

The Royal Geographical Society (with the Institute of British Geographers) has developed some fantastic teaching resources on the Arctic and Antarctic in conjunction with the British Antarctic Survey and Foreign and Commonwealth Office. The websites this team have created together www.discoveringthearctic.org.uk and www.discoveringantarctica.org.uk/ which are full of videos, images, audio and resources for schools to use. Instructions on how to use can be found in the teachers' area.

Particularly good are the interactives. Being there provides a great background to the Antarctic. Children get to imagine they are a location scout and wannabe scriptwriter for a Hollywood movie company setting out to make a film about the Antarctic using this make a trailer interactive.

What's the difference between the Antarctic and the Arctic? This interactive explains.

We can't understand what's happening in the Arctic and Antarctic now without going back to how it was formed in the first place. This interactive on how super continent Gondwana broke up is really helpful.

So why are Antarctica and the Arctic such important places for studying climate change? These interactives on the biggest seasonal change on earth and the importance of polar science explore the issues.

Students can also find out more about the work of scientists based at Rothera Research Station in the Antarctic who collect data from the land, sea and air.

WWF's report goes into detail about the impact of climate change on the Russian Arctic and ways to solve some of the problems. Also see safeguarding the natural world and the related activity. Older students may be interested in joining Greenpeace's Save the Arctic campaign focusing on a ban on oil drilling, or join discussion on Twitter #savethearctic.

And for younger pupils see Twinkl's gorgeous Arctic-themed borders, display posters, play masks and word mats. Animal fans will also enjoy making an Origami Arctic fox using these instructions.

Thanks to teacher Ron Gordon for his basic PowerPoint introducing global warming with some simple exercises. You can find explanation of global warming and the causes for it here.

Older students and teachers will find the Guardian's Everything you need to know about climate change interactive invaluable for a one-stop guide to the facts of global warming.

Camelot, the winner of the 2,000 Guineas and Derby, ran 5lb below his best form when he was beaten at Doncaster on Saturday in the St Leger, the final leg of the Triple Crown, according to the British Horseracing Authority's handicapper.

Camelot has been rated 119 for his performance at Town Moor, the same mark he achieved in the Guineas at Newmarket but 1lb behind the winner Encke, who improved by 8lb on his previous rating of 112.

Camelot improved to 124 when he stretched five lengths clear of Main Sequence, the runner-up, in the Derby in early June.

The BHA's figures are closely matched by those of the Timeform organisation, which assessed Camelot as running 6lb below his best form at Doncaster. Prior to the race Timeform described Camelot as a "certainty" to complete the Triple Crown but after his three-quarter length defeat by Encke his "master" rating has been reduced from 130 to 128 and his Leger run assessed at 122.

"The Derby form is not working out as well as we hoped it might at the time," David Johnson, Timeform's Flat editor, said . "Obviously it was disappointing that Camelot could not win the Leger. Even his new rating of 128 should have been good enough to win a typical Leger but, for whatever reason, he was not the Camelot we saw in the Derby.

"The hope now is that he is not just rushed off to stud. We need to see him in a race like the Arc or the Champion Stakes or racing as a four-year-old. It would be a real shame if he went out on a performance like that."

With the Coolmore Stud syndicate which owns Camelot still considering the options for their colt, there was little sign in the ante-post markets that another outing for the Derby winner is imminent. Camelot has been removed from the betting for the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe by all major bookmakers while he could be backed at over 20-1, albeit for tiny sums, on the Betfair betting exchange on Monday evening.

The Arc betting was largely unchanged following the trials meeting at Longchamp on Sunday, although the French Derby winner Saonois, who was available at 12-1 after winning the Prix Niel, is now no bigger than 10-1. The Niel has historically been the best of the three Arc trials staged three weeks before the race itself, with Arc winners including Bago, Dalakhani and Sinndar having contested both races since 2000, although there is now a six-year gap since Rail Link became the last Niel winner to take the Arc.

Maarek, the top weight for the Ayr Gold Cup, the big betting race in Britain this weekend, could yet line up for the race despite having won the Group Three Greenlands Stakes at The Curragh three days ago.

"If it comes up soft enough we'll run," David Nagle, Maarek's trainer, said. "He's in good form and there's no other suitable race until Ascot [on 20 October]. I'll probably claim off him and [5lb claimer] Mark Enright will probably ride.

"He's been on the go a long time, he ran on the first day of the season at The Curragh but he's holding his form brilliantly. He beat Gordon Lord Byron at Naas, giving him 5lb, and he [Gordon Lord Byron] won at York [in August] and finished second in a Group One [the Sprint Cup at Haydock]."

BetFred, which took control of the Tote last year and with it the sponsorship of the Gold Cup at Cheltenham, has extended its deal to support the Festival's showpiece event for the next three years.

"People from all walks of life get excited by the Betfred Cheltenham Gold Cup," Paul Fisher, group managing director of Jockey Club Racecourses, said on Monday, "and we look forward to continuing to grow its unique appeal."

Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Lebanon's powerful Hezbollah movement, has called for new demonstrations to express outrage at a film that denigrates Islam and the prophet Muhammad, as unrest triggered by it continues from Tunisia to Indonesia.

"Prophet of God, we offer ourselves, our blood and our kin for the sake of your dignity and honour," Nasrallah told supporters who chanted "death to Israel" and "death to America" at a rally in the southern Shia suburbs of Beirut. "The US should understand that if it broadcasts the film in full it will face very dangerous repercussions around the world."

Nasrallah, who fears assassination by Israel, appears in public only rarely. Political opponents suggested that anger over the film, Innocence of Muslims, was a useful diversion from the bloody crisis in neighbouring Syria, where the Assad government, along with Iran, is a patron of the Lebanese militant group.

In Tunis, police surrounded a mosque where a Salafi leader was meeting followers. Sheikh Saif-Allah Benhassine is wanted by police over clashes at the US embassy last week, but he managed to slip past the cordon and escape.

President Barack Obama called US diplomatic staff in Sudan, Tunisia, Libya and Yemen at the weekend, to reassure them that their security is a top priority for the US government.

Reflecting nervousness about the protests in the region, the US embassy in Beirut has started to destroy classified material as a security precaution, the Associated Press reported.

In Benghazi, Libya's second city, the Islamist brigade suspected of involvement in the death of US ambassador Chris Stevens last week said that America was to blame for allowing the release of the film.

"We categorically deny we were there," said Youssef el-Gehani, spokesman of the Ansar al-Sharia brigade. "American policies target some of the most sacred elements of our religion so you should expect a reaction," he told the Guardian. "The embassy [US consulate] knew how sensitive it was to have that film, they should have evacuated the embassy."

At the weekend, Libya's de facto head of state, Mohamed al-Magariaf, said Ansar al-Sharia members were involved in the night-long assault that left four US consulate staff dead. He linked the group to al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb.

Gehani warned that the US would continue to face attacks in Muslim countries. "If America wants respect in the Arab world, it should avoid spilling blood in places such as Syria and Afghanistan, and avoid insulting the prophet."

His comments came amid chaos within Libya's government, with the deputy interior minister, Wanis al-Sharif, being sacked after claiming that 50 suspects had been arrested in connection with the attack on the anniversary of 9/11. The interior minister, Fawzi Abdul Al, insisted only four arrests had been made.

On Sunday a video was released showing Stevens was still alive when he was found after the attack. A Libyan witness told the Associated Press that Stevens was still breathing, though his face was blackened and he seemed paralysed.

In Pakistan, the prime minister, Raja Pervaiz Ashraf, ordered the suspension of YouTube over the "blasphemous" Muhammad film. Two protesters were killed as police used teargas and fired into the air to control crowds which have grown since last week. Thousands of people shouting anti-American slogans took to the streets in Peshawar, Lahore, and, for a second day, in Karachi.

Violent rage also spread to Kabul in Afghanistan, with hundreds of people taking to the streets, burning tyres and a car, and attacking police and a US base with stones.

Indonesian police fired teargas and water cannon to disperse hundreds of demonstrators who massed outside the US embassy in Jakarta, the capital of the world's most populous Muslim country.

Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, was quoted on state TV as saying that western leaders must prove they were not "accomplices" in a "big crime".

In Egypt, two prominent figures are facing legal action over broadcasting a clip of the film. Khaled Abdallah, an ultra-conservative television anchor, and Nader Bakkar, spokesman of the Salafi al-Nour party, stand accused of instigating violence that led to the storming of the US embassy in Cairo.

Tony Blair, meanwhile, told the BBC that the offending film was "wrong and offensive but also laughable as a piece of film-making". He added: "What is dangerous and wrong is the reaction to it."

The family of Nakoula Basseley Nakoula left their California home in the middle of the night on Monday and have been taken to an undisclosed location, a Los Angeles police spokesman said.

Nakoula has been identified by US federal authorities as the key figure behind Innocence of Muslims.

Stanley Houghton was part of the Manchester school of playwrights that did so much to enliven British drama in the years before the first world war. And this excellent revival of Houghton's 1912 play reminds us of his virtues: a firm sense of structure, a rejection of fossilised attitudes, and a passionate belief in female independence.

Houghton's play is, among other things, an assault on moral rigidity, whether it comes from the workers or their bosses. The trouble starts when the working-class Hawthorns discover that their daughter, Fanny, has spent a dirty weekend in Llandudno with Alan Jeffcote, son of the local mill-owner. Shock and horror ensues with both the sternly self-righteous Mrs Hawthorn and the self-made Jeffcote senior arguing that the young couple have no alternative but to get married. Houghton complicates the issue, however, by asking us to consider first the feelings of Alan's fiancee, and then the proto-feminist leanings of the suddenly articulate Fanny.

Somewhat disingenuously, Houghton said his play was simply "an entertainment". In reality, it exposes the sexual double-standards of the period. When Alan describes his fling with Fanny as "just an amusement, a lark", it is considered understandable; when Fanny uses almost exactly the same words, Alan is profoundly shocked. And the commodification of sex is neatly captured when Alan's father indignantly asks: "Why hadn't thou the sense to pay for thy pleasures instead of getting mixed up with a straight girl?"

The tension sags only in the stilted encounter between Alan and his fiancee. Otherwise, Houghton's play belongs to an extraordinary period in British drama that, within the space of a year, yielded George Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion and Githa Sowerby's Rutherford & Son – both plays, like his, about women finding their voice in accordance with shifts in society.

Bethan Dear's strongly cast revival not only brings out Houghton's progressive instinct, but also deftly conveys the play's internal marital tensions. Richard Durden's arrogantly assertive Mr Jeffcote and Anna Carteret's hectoring Mrs Hawthorn are clearly two of a kind: Susan Penhaligon and Peter Ellis, as their respective partners, reveal softer, more forgiving natures. Ellie Turner also conveys Fanny's emergence from deceptive lies to downright truth and Graham O'Mara pins down Alan's moral hypocrisy. As with the Royal Exchange's 1998 revival, we are reminded what a resilient play this is and what a loss was Houghton's death in 1913. And who is to say that, 100 years after Hindle Wakes, we still don't live in a world that has one law for sexually adventurous men and another for women?

Professor John Butt is of that rare breed: a music academic who is also a genuinely thrilling performer. As one of the world's foremost Bach scholars, he brings vigorous insight to the period ensemble he conducts from the harpsichord, the Edinburgh-based Dunedin Consort. But there's flamboyancy and pathos in his musicianship, too, that always cuts to the heart of a work's emotional drama. This performance of Bach's St John Passion, opening the Lammermuir festival and giving a glimpse into Dunedin's forthcoming recording of the piece, was a case in point.

Forces were stripped down to one-per-part in orchestra and voices – eight singers in total – so that the soloists also formed the chorus. A few moments wanted more oomph from the strings, particularly the surging opening chorus, but generally the ensemble sounded lithe and mellow, and the singers shone with artful, pinpoint precision. The chorus played its fickleness well: swaggering as soldiers, nitpicking as law abiders, snidely jovial as chief priests. Nicholas Mulroy was particularly strong as the Evangelist, with a beguilingly sweet tenor and a knack for compelling storytelling; Robert Davies was a noble Pilate. I should admit that due to a nasty (and noisy) cough, I spent a sizeable chunk of Part One listening from the kitchenette at the back of the church, but even from here the diction came across loud and clear.

The gripping underlying drama came from Butt's masterful handling of pace, both in tiny nuances and broad architecture. Totally attuned to the harmonic framework of the piece, he breathed space into all the right places, built frenetic tension to the point of the crucifixion and allowed a palpable sense of release at the crux line, "Es ist vollbracht" (All is fulfilled).

• This article was amended on 19 September 2012. The original referred to Robert Davies as a noble Pilot. That should, of course, have been Pilate, and has been corrected.

The headlines will undoubtedly be made by the continued absence – or otherwise – of Kevin Pietersen, but when England finally announce their squad for the four-Test tour of India , the young Yorkshire opener Joe Root is expected to be confirmed as the man seen as the likeliest long-term successor to Andrew Strauss at the top of the order.

The 21-year-old Root who started his career at the same Sheffield club as Michael Vaughan, was named by the Cricket Writers' Club as the 64th winner of the Young Cricketer of the Year award on Monday – and dropped a pleasingly naïve hint in his acceptance speech that it will not be the last recognition he receives this week.

While the appointment of Alastair Cook to take over as the captain in Test as well as one-day cricket following Strauss's retirement was a formality, there has been much more conjecture about who would replace the former captain as Cook's opening partner in India.

Michael Carberry, Nick Compton and Varun Chopra have all been proposed as contenders from county cricket, and England also had the option of promoting Jonathan Trott or Ian Bell. But Root has been regarded as the coming man for a while, having been selected regularly for the England Lions and worked especially closely with Graham Thorpe.

He had a solid, if not overwhelming, season playing Division Two cricket with Yorkshire. But the India tour, while a daunting challenge in many ways, could be seen as a good opportunity to expose a young opener ahead of the back-to-back Ashes series that lie ahead in 2012-13.

Inevitably, the uncertainty surrounding Pietersen is a relevant factor, as his absence in India would leave England reluctant to rob their middle order of further experience by promoting Trott or Bell. The general expectation is that Pietersen will be omitted, which would represent a fourth snub in little more than a month after he was dropped from the third Test against South Africa, left out of the World Twenty20 squad and stripped of his central contract.

But following the five-day delay in the squad announcement which was originally due last Thursday, no one will know for sure until England's national selector Geoff Miller brings the saga to a close with his first public uttering for almost a month on Tuesday morning.

If Pietersen is left out, that would raise further questions over when, or whether, he might ever play for England again. Omission would leave him free to play for his Indian Premier League franchise Delhi Daredevils in the Champions League t20 competition in South Africa next month, and then to take up one of the offers he has received to appear in Australia's Big Bash Twenty20 tournament in December and January.

The next opportunity for England inclusion would come in the five-match one-day series in India in the New Year, which is followed by more limited-overs games in New Zealand before a three-Test series begins in March. But another snub would represent a huge test of the commitment to England which he expressed in the You Tube interview during which he rescinded his one-day international retirement last month.

Like England's team director, Andy Flower, and his Twenty20 squad, Pietersen will be in Colombo when the squad is confirmed. He flew to Sri Lanka on Monday ahead of his media commitments in the ICC World Twenty20 tournament, having signed up to work as a pundit for ESPN Star Sports in the period between his retirement from one-day international cricket in May and his offer to rescind that decision in August.

Looming in the background are consecutive Ashes series, in England in the second half of next summer then Australia in the winter of 2013-14. Perhaps Pietersen will reveal his plans on ESPN.

When the competition is stronger, you need to be smarter, nimbler and more imaginative to survive. Pitted against the commercial muscle of France, Italy and the US, British fashion lives on its wits. And those who dismiss fashion as vacuous should know that new ideas are essential to selling frocks.

The ideas fuelling the latest crop of London fashion week shows were drawn from sources near and far: from an east London park to Florence and Rajasthan via Outer Space.

For Christopher Kane, inspiration struck during a walk in Victoria Park, near the Olympic Park in east London, with his sister and close collaborator, Tammy, and her baby daughter. Christopher noticed the ornate wingnuts on the ironwork of a bridge. Something about the shape chimed with his studio experimentation with taking a bow motif, that symbol of don't-frighten-the-horses ladylike dressing, as the starting point for something bold and sculptural.

"We started with something sickly sweet, and messed it up until we ended up somewhere darker," he said. With bolts and wingnuts remade in clear plastic as fastenings on ribbon folds of fabric – milk white, sugar pink and daffodil yellow – the collection took on a life of its own, a wardrobe for a pastel Frankenstein's monster.

From the very first outfit – a biker jacket suit in white leather relief-embossed with roses – it was a collection fired with drama and perfectly pitched to please Kane's young, fashion-crazed fanbase.

Erdem is adult and well-mannered, where Christopher Kane is young and raucous. (To signal this to anyone who hadn't picked it up, Jessie Ware joined the Alexa Chung gang in the front row at Kane, while Lady Mary from Downton Abbey observed Erdem with aristocratic poise, chaperoned by Vogue staffers).

But the humour and detail in Erdem's clothes appeals to women whose poise masks a mischievous streak, a fact neatly reflected in the story he told backstage about the genesis of his collection: it was inspired, he said, by a 1950s science fiction short story about reptilian aliens who try to blend in as respectable women. Slivers of python were inserted between slices of lace. Fifties detailing – back vents that give a cocoon silhouette, ornate crystal necklaces – were set off-kilter by pretty colours used in deliberately odd combinations: fuschia, yellow and tangerine, for example.

Peter Pilotto is a Dalston-based label whose graphic pieces are currently scoring high across the celebrity matrix. As well as regular glossy magazine appearances, the label was recently worn by Princess Beatrice to the Olympic Park. Peter Pilotto – a duo, confusingly, despite the name – are at the vanguard of a revolutionary London fashion movement which has reinvented print for a generation of women who considered traditional patterns old hat.

Like Mary Katrantzou, whose weekend show reworked imagery from postage stamps and banknotes, they take a rich, cultured aesthetic and use modern technology to make it into something more accessible. Colours and patterns which once had a tendency to stifle the clothes with museum-piece nostalgia are digitally engineered into something more digestible to the modern palate.

The latest catwalk collection showcased new latest advances in digital engineering. Working with a new software programme that enables designers Peter Pilotto and his partner, Christophe De Vos, to experiment with infinite combinations of layered patterns – a process they describe as "a digital kaleidoscope" – they spliced ideas taken from early English calligraphy, images from Florentine frescoes, and colour combinations they fell in love with during a summer holiday in Rajasthan. The impact of the software on these dense visuals is a little like putting reams of statistics into a spreadsheet. The finished product is infinitely more accessible.

The effect of print layering is counterintuitive. One might expect that a geometric dark grid laid on top of swirls of bright colour would dampen the impact, but instead it seems to serve as a harness, channelling the energy of the look into something more dynamic. On dresses, slim trousers and the label's bestselling curvy pencil skirts, print and silhouette were in harmony.

The imprint of other London catwalk shows seemed to have fed in to the collection at times – the marbling that was the focus of Stella McCartney's one-off London show in February, and the baroque sensibility of Mary Katrantzou – but the result was surprising and fresh. This collection may not match the commercial splash made by its autumn predecessor – that had a coherent, recognisable thread that this more complicated show perhaps lost – but it promises a bright future nonetheless.

Technical innovation in print and fabric is a key factor in the dynamism of London fashion. Fabrics on Kane's catwalk this season include basketweave silks and injection-moulded rubber, while Erdem worked with an embroidery company in Switzerland experimenting with the use of classic couture techniques on modern plasticised fabric.

Antonio Berardi, keen to show a sportier side to a label known for exquisite taste and refined sex appeal, experimented with a new Aertex-effect mesh that holds its shape while maintaining the freshness of openwork. "The only problem is, it is incredibly expensive," admitted the designer after the show. "I am always asking, how can we make this better. My pattern cutters kind of hate me, because it makes things very complicated. But my clothes aren't cheap, so they should be really special."

The collection, which referenced the Chrysler building and the work of Frank Lloyd Wright, was shown in a catwalk fashioned out of the third floor of a Soho carpark, an appropriate juxtaposition for a designer who refuses to compromise on the quality and workmanship of his clothes.

Compared to most labels on the London fashion week schedule, Burberry are in financial clover, but in the past few weeks their upbeat trajectory has slackened. Chief creative officer Christopher Bailey's response was a fun, upbeat catwalk show that wore the brand's heritage lightly. "The environment is challenging right now," admitted Bailey. "All we can do is try to have a strong point of view, which is joyous and sexy and makes people excited about fashion."

The "very British glamour" of Norman Parkinson photos and an archive photo of an early twentieth century Burberry corset were the starting point for a collection of corsetted cocktail dresses in rustling Quality Street shades of satin, worn with capes and loose jackets of coloured perspex and luxe gaberdine.

The much-maligned Burberry check, banished below stairs in recent seasons, was revived for tongue-in-cheek bags trimmed with neon animal skin. Bailey is optimistic for the check's future: "I think it should be something which makes people smile," he said.

6.05pm BST

Afternoon summary

• Michael Gove has claimed that abolishing GCSEs will end years of "drift, decline and dumbing down" in England's exam system. In a statement on exam reform, he said that GCSEs were "designed for a different age" and that pupils would start studying for the new qualifications in September 2015, taking the exams for the first time in 2017. His plans were published in full in the Mail on Sunday yesterday and the only significant new fact in the announcement was the name of the new exam, the English baccalaureate certificate. Gove said that changing the exam would enable English pupils to compete with the best in the world.

We plan to call these new qualifications - in core academic subjects - English Baccalaureate Certificates - recognising that they are the academic foundation which is the secure base on which further study, vocational learning or a satisfying apprenticeship can be built. Success in English, maths, the sciences, a humanities subject and a language will mean that the student has the full English Baccalaureate.

Now some will argue that more rigorous qualifications in these subjects will inevitably lead to more students failing. But we believe that fatalism is indicative of a dated mind-set; one that believes in a distribution of abilities so fixed that great teaching can do little to change.

And we know that great teaching is changing lives even as we speak. We have the best generation of teachers and headteachers we have ever had. Their excellence combined with reforms and improvements to education that this Government are making through improved teacher training, greater freedoms for head teachers and the growth of academies and free schools will mean more students will be operating at a higher level.

So even as exams become more rigorous, more students will be equipped to clear this higher bar. Indeed, we are explicitly ambitious for all our children – and we believe that over time we will catch up with the highest performing nations and a higher proportion of children will clear the bar than now.

Gove adopted a belligerent tone in his statement, accusing Labour of devaluing GCSEs by introducing modules and extending the use of coursework. But, if the Daily Mail report from earlier this summer about his plans was accurate (and no one is suggesting that it was not), Gove has retreated in some respects. The introduction of the new exam has been postponed and at this stage he is only proposing that pupils start studying for the English baccalaureate certificate in English, maths and science from September 2015; other subjects will follow at some unspecified point in the future.

• Stephen Twigg, the shadow education secretary, has said that Labour will not support exam reform that does not benefit all pupils. Responding to Gove's statement in the Commons, Twigg said:

The education leaving age is rising to 18, we need to face the challenges of the 21st century. But I simply don't accept that we achieve that by returning to a system abolished as out of date in the 1980s. Instead, we need a system that promotes rigour and breadth, and prepares young people for the challenges of the modern economy.

Gove said that Twigg's comments showed that Labour was failing to embrace reform.

• Teaching unions have strongly condemned the plans. Chris Keates, general secretary of the NASUWT, said: "The secretary of state has embarked from the outset on a cynical and wholly unjustifiable attempt to discredit the quality and rigour of the GCSE qualification." And Christine Blower, the general secretary of the NUT, said Gove's approach was "nonsensical".

That's it from me for today. Thanks for the comments.

Michael Gove has issued a 19-page consultation paper on his plans (pdf). Here's an extract from the summary.

1.1 This consultation sets out the Government’s plans to restore rigour and confidence to our examination system at age 16, which has been undermined by years of continued grade inflation. We need to raise the level of challenge in our Key Stage 4 qualifications to match the best in the world. Raising our expectations of attainment for all students will drive up standards as teaching and learning improve to
meet that challenge. High expectations are essential to creating a step change in standards and allowing us to keep pace with our international competitors.

1.2. Our proposals will restore confidence by ending the perverse incentives created by the interaction of our qualifications and accountability system. At present, schools are incentivised to boost their performance by seeking examinations in which they believe their students may achieve higher grades, and Awarding Organisations have a corresponding incentive to compete for market share by
